CARDINAL . The Law on Legal Acts prescribes the types and hierarchy of legal acts in GPE . The relevant provisions of the PERSON , as in force at the material time , provided as follows .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL listed the legal acts adopted in GPE which included , inter alia , LAW , the NORP laws and the decrees of the Government .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the LAW laid down the principles of legal regulation on the territory of GPE and was the legal foundation of the NORP legislation . It had supreme legal force and its provisions were directly applicable . The laws and other legal acts were adopted on the basis of the LAW or for the purpose of its implementation and were not to contradict it .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that laws regulated the most important , inherent and stable social relations and were enacted in compliance with the LAW through a referendum or by ORG . They were not to contradict LAW , the active laws and the decisions of ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provided that the Government adopted decrees within the scope of the powers vested in it by the LAW and the laws . The decrees of the Government were not to contradict LAW , the laws and the decisions of ORG . They were to regulate any relations not regulated by the laws , unless those relations , pursuant to the LAW and the laws or the edicts and directives of the President of GPE , were to be regulated by other legal acts .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provided that the decisions of ORG were final and not subject to appeal . They entered into force from the moment of their delivery and had a binding effect on the territory of GPE .

CARDINAL . When deciding on the conformity of paragraphs CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL of Section CARDINAL of the LAW with , inter alia , LAW , the Constitutional Court provided the following interpretation of that provision . Since the phrases “ for the needs of society and the ORG ” and “ only in exceptional cases ” were concepts requiring assessment and concerned a fundamental constitutional right , the LAW stipulated that expropriation of property on such grounds could be carried out only on the basis of a law , thereby creating necessary legislative safeguards . The phrase “ on the basis of a law ” implied not a normative legal act which regulated the expropriation procedure in general , but a law pursuant to which the property in question was to be expropriated . Thus , a person ’s property could be expropriated and – in the absence of his consent – his ownership could be terminated by the ORG only through the adoption of a law in respect of the concrete immovable property , which would substantiate the exceptional importance and significance of the expropriation and which would indicate the needs of society and the ORG to be satisfied by the expropriation . The law would also oblige the Government to fix the amount of compensation , taking market prices into account , on the basis of a financial - economic assessment , the results of the negotiation between the ORG and the owner of the property subject to expropriation , and upon the owner ’s written consent . The ORG was not entitled to establish a procedure for expropriation of property for the needs of society and the ORG that would authorise it to expropriate immovable property .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provided that members of the tenant ’s family included his spouse , their children and their parents . Other persons could be recognised as the tenant ’s family members , if they lived with him or her and ran a common household .

Article CARDINAL provided that family members of the owner of a house , whom the owner had accommodated in his or her house , had the right , equally with him or her , to use the accommodation , if no reservations had been made at the time when the family members were accommodated . Persons mentioned in the first sentence of LAW were considered as members of the owner ’s family . These persons were to continue to enjoy the right of use of accommodation even in case of disruption of family ties with the owner .

CARDINAL . The right of use of accommodation may not be an object of sale or purchase , mortgage and lease .
